comments.commentBody: This issue alone should create a groundswell of support for Bernie Sanders.
Jerry, you are obviously getting your "information" from Faux News. Get your facts right, then rant if you must but it will be directed at the GOP, not President Obama.
Automation.

No, they can't. But the treaty is not really about workers, it is a matter of foreign policy the tail wagging the dog. The condition of workers is secondary in the sense that foreign policy in this globalized world has immense economic consequences. Foreign policy needs to be brought under democratic control, not just when it affects workers.

Mexico just won a WTO ruling against the US for labeling tuna as dolphin safe. This process is already ongoing. TPP would just give the option to more companies and countries.
http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/04/14/us-usa-mexico-tuna-idUSKBN0N51...

It is much too late to offset China's domination of world markets -- especially in its own backyard.  In fifteen more years, the roles will be completely reversed with China as the leading economic and military power in the world and the USA as a third-world country with nukes.

This is long-established usage from the New York Times Style Book (now available electronically), and hardly began with this president. (AP, by the way, often refers to presidents, candidates and other politicians on second and subsequent references with only the last name; thus, "Obama" or "Romney" with no disrespect to be found.)

Nothing to be irate about here, no matter how hard you may wish otherwise.

Why is TPP classified like a military secret? TPP is not nuclear war, it's not spying. Maybe it's classified because Obama doesn't want workers to know that they can kiss their jobs goodbye if TPP goes through.

The proposed text of the TPP should not be classified; rather, the American people deserve a robust debate about this proposed pact. The American people have every right to read and question its every detail, given both its enormous scale and the disastrous consequences of earlier trade pacts such as NAFTA. NAFTA's legacy: Good-paying U.S. manufacturing jobs were shipped overseas, where the workers now suffer miserable wages and unsafe conditions that are sometimes tantamount to slavery.

All too true and all too shameful.  The Han Chinese have steadily moved from taking over land to systematically destroying almost all vestiges of the endemic culture of their ethnic and religious minorities.  In some areas of the country they've encouraged the locals to dress up in traditional costumes and perform traditional dances for the (mostly Han) tourists from the east coast.  I've seen some of these shows and they're absolutely ghastly but it's one of the few means by which the minority-folk get to earn some sort of a living.
Bill, you aren't the only one with a green screen.

Again no mention of investor state dispute settlement, ISDS. And we are supposed to take the NY Times seriously?

What American workers need is tariffs, the last thing multinationals would stand for. So it really is class war: American workers versus multinational corporations who are making a play to nullify American sovereignty itself.
Obama is a corporation man. No bankster arrests. Approved article drilling. He's a Rockefeller Republican. He is a causation unreality though he plays one from time to time

Unlike other jobs, deployment is simply a very tough job. I can never understand, American deployments since these are indirect wars and certainly not direct. These wars are simply imposed by the politicians and arms lobby in the military, meant to cause not only unnecessary stress and strain to the soldiers and their families but also causes irreversible and avoidable damage to the soldiers and their families either in the form of loss of limbs or lives of the soldiers.

I think, this kind of feeling " who has it worse " can surely be avoided by winding up unnecessary wars but will the powers that matter do it, it's a million dollars question I suppose.

Rosebud is a sled!

Wags,

Have you been to STROMboli, accent on the STROM? They got it right in the 1950 Ingrid Bergman movie, "Stromboli, " but ususally as with CApri, the acCENT is on the wrong sylLABle.

.
"Vote fraud rampant in the US"??

I hope you're referring to candidates who accept votes after defrauding the electorate into believing they know how to do the jobs they seek. You know, like much of the US House of Representatives.

Or manipulation of the vote-count process, or the unwarranted removal of voters from the rolls, or policies that forbid students from voting in the jurisdictions where they attend college.

But if you're talking about people voting under 37 names, or people registering to vote without meeting the criteria to legally register, I do believe you are lost in a world of myth.

On the other hand, we can certainly agree that corruption in Albany should be investigated thoroughly. Tirelessly. Ad nauseam, until it is removed root and branch.

Let me put it gently:

the story hit big because a) it was on the NYT front page for two days; b) it was journalism at its finest.

Perhaps your editor could try this formula again with, say, the corruption in Albany? - or the vote fraud rampant in the US? - or the fraud charter schools and standardized testing perpetrate on education? - or dozens of other issues.

If you wanna sell newspapers, tell the truth so convincingly it will even make a comatose politician pay attention.
Project much? Condescend to half the human race more? I strongly suggest keeping your opinions on subjects you cannot possibly understand to yourself .

I think, self - blame in the case of miscarriage is more to do with the educated and very much less to do with the uneducated women.

Generally speaking, educated women tend to dig deep into everything. It means, they think, read, interpret and imagine too much and also due to the exposure to the outside world in the larger context, which sometimes might end up as some kind of disadvantage for them. In any case, miscarriage is quite painful to the woman concerned whether educated or not.

Uneducated women simply think that if a child is born, it's purely God's grace and in the event of a miscarriage, they treat it as God's curse on them. In one way, it's a blessing. At least, they won't be cursing themselves lifelong.

I gave up coffee for ten months because I thought it was not good for me to drink. Well, for ten months I constantly missed my coffee and felt lethargic the entire time. After I drank a cup of coffee finally I felt normal again. I love the stuff and drink it "boot black and gritty" every morning.
You might need to do a little research on your assumption. There are millions who are highly educated and still believe in a higher power. Maybe you should rephrase your post to educated humanists.
Tim,  you should take a hard look at Thomas Aquinas, who lived 800 years ago and has clearly shown that "educated" people know there is a God.
Dennis:  Your response is analogous to saying that since John at the pizza store is 6'2", the average height of Americans cannot be 5'10" .

The better educated a population is, the higher the percentage that define themselves as non-believers. Unless, of course, some of the better educated are profiting from the religious devotion of the less learned.

That has been true throughout history. The only difference is the greater number of better educated people thriving in the modern world, versus the lesser numbers in past decades, and centuries.

Still, as long as there is money in religion, there will be buyers and sellers of belief in religion.

.
@ ELFin yekKE ...

Well, I hope you enjoyed the enquiry at least!

I will content myself knowing that, if need be, you 2 would be able to pith amphibians.

I do hope I was not to intrusive!!

ELF, When we were there in 1960 the Soviets had already pulled out and the people in Austria, including Wien, were more pro-American than most Americans are today.  We felt more welcome in that country than almost any other (though the Italians in a small town on the way to Venice were also very warm). The French were aloof. The Belgians were indifferent. The Dutch were polite. And the Germans were Germans.  The Autobahn was more inviting.

and Elke (aka ELF)
John-
it's also Robert's favourite movie. He saw it being filmed in Vienna in 1949 - near the Schwedenplatz which was in rubbles still. Of course the Prater Riesenrad (Ferris wHEEL) is still a tourist attraction. Your avatar was christened with a long moniker.......for a long walk...
As ARTE would say "it's verrrrry interesting" that clue 22A calls "series of comments" a THREAD- it doesn't happen enough here; it's SHRED instead.
Tried to fit "cheval" ( instead of PORC) as alternative for boeuf and jambon- it would be in France....:))
Martin-
thank you for that 1951 link of the Weaver's (Tzena)x3. yesterday. It brought back happy memories of youth activities that decade..
MTFTobin-
I am availing myself of door #1 :"you need not answer" Thanks.
Was looking for "rosebud" or a sled in the puzzle; it was an ACE nevertheless.
Hearing a zither in my ear.
Good night..

“We’re not trying to go, like, suck in and devour everything.”

Well, no, not yet! But just give them a few years... (Remember when Amazon only sold books?) Facebook is the company that always forces people to opt out of new features it adds on the sly... and then backpedals when privacy advocates loudly complain. I hope the publishers who have signed on for this keep that in mind.

This doesn't take care of the author's concerns about muddying the waters of her unconscious and counter-transference involvements, but it is an excellent idea.  Although they might have a hard time admitting it, I believe psychoanalysts also have basic run-of-the-mill ego needs and desires for fame and success and want to be recognized for their talents.  Otherwise, the pseudonym approach seems like a good answer.

.
She would have also been appropriate for Joe Krozel's puzzle, whose theme, Franklie, was the 4 Seasons.

I have personally resolved the Favorite Film dilemma in favor of the 1st Godfather film, after adhering to Citizen Kane for 15-20 years. In fairness to the worthy Casablanca, I never saw that one in a theater. But Peter Lorre and Sidney Greenstreet don't have big enough roles for my taste.
Do you have a link to that browser add-on you installed?
Google "FB Purity" and "Adblock."
David, thanks!  Most valuable comment!

"... and The New York Times, have agreed to the deal, despite concerns that their participation could eventually undermine their own businesses."

Frightened into agreeing, it sounds like. Don't worry about me. Someone will publish a browser add-on to block these news stories and I will install it, just as I have installed a blocker for their stupid "Trending" and ads that could not possibly be of interest to me.

Ikebana class tonight. Scouring for materials Friday for an arrangement at the San Francisco headquarters Saturday and a master class Sunday.

I previewed your reveal on youtube. It's wonderful. The music is great and seeing it created is humbling.

I remember convincing my mother to take me on a Ferris wheel when I was maybe 8, unaware of her acrophobia. I guess she didn't want to disappoint me. She had a major panic attack at the top and begged me to get her down. Pretty traumatic all around.
